purpose: The purpose of this channel is to discuss the architecture and requirements for an event infrastructure for fabric nodes
text: <@U0PB67X4K|garisingh> set the channel purpose: The purpose of this channel is to discuss the architecture and requirements for an event infrastructure for fabric nodes
A few words about events as an introduction for new comers benefit.
Fabric’s invoke and deploy requests are “submitted”  and return an transaction ID. They are then executed asynchronously.
One can poll for completion of transaction or have an Event listener to learn about them.
Events do not send out “transaction” complete. They only send out “block” complete.

The only event _currently_ supported by Events is “block”. There is work on “Custom” or “Chaincode” events (<https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/wiki/Custom-Events-High-level-specification>) where chaincode can emit events

<@U13TWBRBL>: I must say I did not expect that

I followed the readme at <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/tree/master/examples/events/block-listener>, only difference is instead of using vagrant, i’m using docker images I built locally (using boot2docker as host vm) and launched “docker run” commands from Mac terminal, mapping ports 5000 and 31315 to host ports, and launched the event-listener from Mac terminal. i also submitted the chaincode “deploy” and “invoke” commands via REST API

btw after re-building the docker images, i’m getting events for successful transactions (as well as legit events reporting errors)
an early prototype for persistent messaging by integrating with Kafka is available here: <https://github.com/jimthematrix/blockchain-features>

attachments.text: blockchain-features - Sandbox for developing features contributed to Hyperledger

text: currently kafka support is statically coded in, but should really have a list of implementations based on a common interface to support different messaging queues (kafka, IBM Integration Bus, MQ, etc.)
are there any tests for the event sending mechanism?
<@U0ULK2JPP>: that only tests the sending mechanism itself
I want to test that if there is a new block is there any event sent or not
no, no bdd test. There is an example under fabric/examples/events/block_listener
and how could I create such a test?
I created a new event type, should I copy block listener and create a new example and use that from bdd tests?
can you add the test to events/events_test.go  ?
but there one has to invoke producer manually
and create an example under fabric/examples/events/
I want to check the overall working of the system
I mean that whether my event is sent in case it should be

my idea was to add a bdd test. bdd tests already use examples (e.g. chancode) and they could also use block_listener. block_listener could be modified to have an option if it has to listen my events too (the default case would be listening only to block events)
and from bdd I could checker whether block listener receiver such an event
right. I don’t know if there’s support for grpc in bddtests
we dont need support because block_listener has that. we only need to use it from the tests, start it as a process and wait for its output
with other words, block_listener is our "event client"
and we check if the system sends out the appropriate events and we get them
so you’ll just start the block_listner process
you could do that. Or you can write another test and have it be a http listener. You might find it easier to integrate it with BDD tests
as its got url support already
in any case I would talk to <@U0UKTPMG8>
he might have other ways you can do it too
I know jeff added more support mechanics in BDD tests recently (althought not sure if there is direct gRPC support)

Hi, a generic question fabric events, do we have a trigger within the fabric to invoke a function when a transaction is received from another peer? this trigger could then be used to generate external business events? Thanks.
chaincode can emit events in response to a transaction

text: so, its slightly inverted from what you are asking, but you could couple the concept of system-cc + custom events to perhaps craft something like you are asking
Thanks <@U0KPFAZNF> , i will check this and get back to you..
I'm looking for good examples of using fabric events
also, looking for preferred approaches of communication between different chain code artifacts

hi theath - fabric events are still under development but there is an example of a client(consumer) in events/consumer that is written in go - we are currently developing a client in nodejs for the sdk but it isn't quite complete
ok, I'm looking for pub sub between chain code
chaincode to chaincode events currently are not supported
what about other chain code to chaincode communication styles?
One question we are wondering about is what is the best place to certain business logic
for instance, a Purchase Order might involve shippers, vendors, customers
There are several items to put on the ledger
PO, LineItem, Invoice, Shipment  each having their own life cycles
they would work together to get an overall smart contract implemented
they assumption is that these artifacts might want to communicate with each other with well known agreed upon events or communcation
there are chaincode to chaincode invokes but that is probably not the answer you were looking for?
currently that is the only method interaction between chaincodes
When Shipments get "Delivered" and Invoice might want to be notified
ok, is it looked down upon to do chaincode to chaincode communication? or is it a best practice
yea, while there are other methods(such as intelligence outside the blockchain), I think you are looking for chaincode to chaincode events
I'm envisioning that "Invoices" want to subscribe to "Shipments"
right, I think keeping the overall smart contact(s) and their intelligence in the block chain  seems important
without having to write "outside the blockchain" code
what we have implemented for chaincode events can be extended such that chaincode can subscribe but the shim support and security issues have not been addressed yet
ok I see, I'm thinking chaincode to chaincode events might be cleaner that direct invokes
ok, would you suggest the best approach for now is too do direct invokes inside the blockchain for now?
or Controller Logic Clients  that try to coordinate related chaincode(s)
yea, that sounds like the best approach for now if want as much of your logic on the blockchain as possible
one thing to consider….. when you do chaincode-chaincode, you are doing 1 transaction, not 2. so Shipments “calling” invoice would be under 1 transaction to ship
since I probably want the Shipment and the Invoice to both get updated in the same scope
yes, In that sense, it is more an organizing principle.
well in that case, its an option
I'm assuming the "event" from the Shipment sent to the Invoice would then  be two transactions
i.e. Shipment updated first, and then Invoice updated later
currently there’s not “events” between chaincodes (as <@U0KQ9QKH6> mentioned)
but nothing preventing Shipment from calling Invoice
ah, right, just wondering if events do come around for chaincode to chaincode that this would be the case
because, this point of yours regarding 1 or 2 transactions is very interesting
it's sounds like direct invokes would be the better approach in this case

Event notifications changed some time within the past few weeks. Does anyone know how to use the new APIs to get events generated by the shim.SetEvent(string , []byte) method? They used to be in the Block's nonhashdata field, but don't seem to be there anymore.
<@U1WGX02HE>: there is a PR to fix that. we are hoping to get that in soon
so it cannot be done at all at the moment?
current fabric supports only one event pet transaction UUID?
ohh...wat if I make a invoke call from one chaincode to second chaincode which also sets an event?
It will replace the event set in second chaincode invoke function?
The event from the first chaincode is the one that can set the event
ohh..it could better if it had an array of events per invoke

[October 13th, 2016 10:19 AM] ashishkel: Hi All, 
We are using events to detect the business logic events from the Chaincode. 
We used the event Client program available in example, as the test program.
And we used our own chaincode to create the events.
And the API used in the Chaincode was 
`err = stub.SetEvent("evtsender3", []byte(tosend))`

And the way we used it is as below 

`tosend := "Event from Invoke_user"`
`err := stub.SetEvent("evtsender1", []byte(tosend))`

`		delay := 5000 * time.Millisecond`
`		time.Sleep(delay)`

`tosend = "Event from Invoke_user with args :"`
`for _, s := range args {`
`	tosend = tosend + "," + s`
`}`
`err = stub.SetEvent("evtsender2", []byte(tosend))`
attachments.text:
Hi All, 
We are using events to detect the business logic events from the Chaincode. 
We used the event Client program available in example, as the test program.
And we used our own chaincode to create the events.
And the API used in the Chaincode was 
`err = stub.SetEvent("evtsender3", []byte(tosend))`

And the way we used it is as below 

`tosend := "Event from Invoke_user"`
`err := stub.SetEvent("evtsender1", []byte(tosend))`

`		delay := 5000 * time.Millisecond`
`		time.Sleep(delay)`

`tosend = "Event from Invoke_user with args :"`
`for _, s := range args {`
`	tosend = tosend + "," + s`
`}`
`err = stub.SetEvent("evtsender2", []byte(tosend))`
